items.title: Apply for 2026 Ohio Farm Bureau Foundation Scholarships
items.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio ‚Äî The Ohio Farm Bureau Foundation has multiple scholarships available to Ohio students from rural, suburban and urban communities who are pursuing degrees with a connection to the agricultural industry. Through 17 scholarship funds, over 50 awards, including two new scholarships, will be given to deserving students in 2026. The deadline to apply […] The post Apply for 2026 Ohio Farm Bureau Foundation Scholarships appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
In 2026, over 50 scholarships will be awarded through 17 different funds. 

The deadline to apply for most scholarships is March 31, 2026, except for the new Ohio Farm Bureau Ambassadors Scholarship, which has a February 28 deadline. The Ambassadors Scholarship provides a $10,000 renewable award for up to 4 years, totaling $40,000.

Other notable scholarships include:
- John Wallace and James Wallace Douglas Scholarship: Supports individuals pursuing agricultural education or careers.
- David E. Mizer Memorial Scholarship: $3,000 renewable scholarship for students from 4 counties studying dairy, food, or agriculture. 
- Mularcik Welding Scholarship: Supports students seeking careers in welding.
- Bill and Helen Swank Scholarship: Honors the legacy of former Ohio Farm Bureau executive.
- Kenny Walter Scholarship: For students from Farm Bureau families in 29 northeastern counties.

In addition to the Foundation's scholarships, many county Farm Bureaus also offer their own scholarship programs. The Foundation aims to inspire and educate the next generation of farmers in Ohio.

items.title: CattleFax Outlook Signals Cattle Cycle Turning
items.description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. ‚Äî The popular CattleFax Outlook Seminar, held as part of CattleCon 2026 in Nashville, Tenn., shared expert market and weather analysis on Feb. 5. ‚ÄúThe U.S. cattle and beef industry enters 2026 with strong but volatile market conditions, as historically tight cattle supplies, record-setting beef demand, and elevated policy and weather uncertainty continue […] The post CattleFax Outlook Signals Cattle Cycle Turning appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. cattle and beef industry in 2026. Despite near-term volatility, the long-term outlook remains positive.

Weather Outlook: La Ni√±a is expected to dissipate by March, leading to a transition period with elevated drought risks in the Southern U.S. and Central Plains. A potential El Ni√±o developing later in the year could impact moisture levels.

Economic Outlook: Inflation moderated to 2.7% in 2025, allowing the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. Corn production reached a record 186.5 bu/acre in 2025, keeping prices between $4-$5/bu. Hay production increased slightly to 123 million tons, with prices around $145/ton.

Cattle Market Outlook:
- The U.S. beef cow herd decreased by 280,000 head, while dairy cow numbers increased by 190,000.
- Feeder cattle supplies will remain constrained in early 2026, leading to a 600,000 head decline in fed slaughter.
- Total beef production is projected to decline again in 2026, but imports are up 5% and exports down 5%, leading to a 0.2 lb increase in per capita beef supply to 59.2 lbs.
- Retail beef demand remained strong in 2025 with record high prices, supported by exceptional beef quality (84% Choice or higher, 12% Prime).
- 2026 cattle and beef prices are forecast to be steady to higher, with cow-calf producers expected to maintain the strongest leverage.
- Key factors to watch include the threat of New World Screwworm, shifts in packing capacity, and growth in the dairy industry supplying more cattle.

items.title: State Agriculture Departments Seek More Markets for Local Meat Processors
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî At the 2026 Winter Policy Conference, National Association of State Departments of Agriculture members encouraged USDA to develop an additional pathway for products from state-inspected meat and poultry processing facilities to be sold across state lines. The policy amendment members passed states that NASDA supports the modification of existing or addition of a […] The post State Agriculture Departments Seek More Markets for Local Meat Processors appeared first on Morning Ag
items.summary:
Currently, these facilities can only sell within their home state, even though they meet the same "at least equal to" USDA standards as federally-inspected plants.

The National Association of State Departments of Agriculture (NASDA) passed a policy amendment at their 2026 Winter Conference supporting this change. NASDA CEO Ted McKinney noted that state agriculture departments have extensive food safety inspection experience and close relationships with local processors, making them well-positioned to help small and medium-sized producers expand their markets.

Many small meat processing facilities are unable to get federal inspections due to limited availability of USDA inspectors. Allowing interstate sales of state-inspected meat would provide more market opportunities for these small businesses, more options for consumers, and save federal resources.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, dates, or expert quotes. It focuses on the policy proposal and potential benefits for small and medium-sized meat processors to gain wider distribution for their products.

During this webinar, Dr. Charlie Hall, of Texas […] The post Farm Credit East Presents Webinar: 2026 Green Industry Economic Outlook appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Farm Credit East will host a free webinar on Monday, February 23, 2026 at 12:00 noon to provide an economic outlook for the green industry in 2026. The webinar will be presented by Dr. Charlie Hall from Texas A&M University.

Key topics to be covered include:
- Growth pattern of the economy
- Supply chain issues
- Labor availability
- Input cost increases
- Inflationary pressures

Dr. Hall will review the green industry's performance in 2025 and give a forecast for 2026, including a recession prediction and strategic responses for green industry participants.

This webinar is part of Farm Credit East's Insights and Perspectives series, which covers various agricultural sectors in the Northeast. Attendees can register for the free webinar at FarmCreditEast.com/Webinars.

Farm Credit East is a member-owned cooperative serving agricultural, forestry, and commercial fishing businesses across an 8-state region. They provide loans, leases, and other financial services to their members.

items.title: Trump Signs Executive Order Boosting Argentine Beef Imports
items.description: February 9, 2025 ‚Äì The United States has finalized a deal with Argentina that is expected to more than quadruple beef imports from the South American country, acting on plans floated in October that received pushback from U.S. cattle producers. On Friday, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to increase Argentine beef imports by […] The post Trump Signs Executive Order Boosting Argentine Beef Imports appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The U.S. has finalized a deal with Argentina that is expected to more than quadruple beef imports from the South American country. On February 9, 2025, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to increase Argentine beef imports by an unspecified amount. This move received pushback from U.S. cattle producers when the plans were first floated in October. The increased beef imports from Argentina are part of the executive order signed by President Trump.

items.title: EPA Reapproves Weedkiller Dicamba Despite Concerns About Drift and Crop Damage
items.description: ‚ÄúThe Trump administration‚Äôs hostility to farmers and rural America knows no bounds,‚Äù Bill Freese, science director at the Center for Food Safety (CFS), said in a press release. ‚ÄúDicamba drift damage threatens livelihoods and tears apart rural communities.‚Äù Farmers have been using dicamba since the 1960s, but issues emerged about a decade ago, when it […] The post EPA Reapproves Weedkiller Dicamba Despite Concerns About Drift and Crop Damage appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has reapproved the use of the weedkiller dicamba despite ongoing concerns about crop damage from dicamba drift. Farmers have been using dicamba since the 1960s, but issues with dicamba drift and crop damage have emerged over the past decade. The Center for Food Safety (CFS) has criticized the decision, stating that "dicamba drift damage threatens livelihoods and tears apart rural communities." The reapproval is part of the Trump administration's policies, which the CFS has described as "hostility to farmers and rural America." The EPA's decision allows the continued use of dicamba on genetically engineered, dicamba-tolerant soybeans and cotton.

items.title: Trump quadruples Argentina beef import quota
items.description: Total in-quota quantify of lean beef trimmings from Argentina will be temporarily increased by 80,000 mt for 2026.
items.summary:
The U.S. has quadrupled the import quota for Argentine beef, increasing it from 20,000 metric tons (mt) to 80,000 mt for 2026. This move is intended to help offset supply chain disruptions and rising beef prices in the U.S. The previous quota of 20,000 mt had been in place since 2015.

The expanded quota will allow more Argentine beef to be imported duty-free into the U.S. Beef exports from Argentina to the U.S. were previously limited to just 20,000 mt per year under a trade agreement.

Argentina's beef production and exports have been rising in recent years, and the country is seeking to grow its market access globally. This increased import quota represents an opportunity for Argentina's beef industry to expand its sales to the lucrative U.S. market.

For U.S. farmers and ranchers, the expanded beef imports from Argentina could put some downward pressure on domestic beef prices, which have been rising due to supply chain issues and strong consumer demand. However, the additional 60,000 mt represents a relatively small fraction of total U.S. beef consumption, so the impact on U.S. producers may be limited.

items.title: Expert says leadership gaps can derail farm succession planning
items.description: A member of the Purdue Ag Alumni Association says having the right succession plan in place is key to preserving the farm for the next generation.  Jim Bishop, owner of Conjunction Leadership, says there needs to be constant communication between generations. “A lot of times, the plan doesn’t really work out like they thought it […] The post Expert says leadership gaps can derail farm succession planning appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Purdue Ag Alumni Association member Jim Bishop says clear succession planning is crucial to passing down the farm
- Communication between generations is key, as many succession plans don't work out as expected
- Lack of leadership skills in the next generation can derail the plan
- Farmers need to identify leadership gaps early and work to develop the next generation's abilities
- Proper succession planning can help ensure the farm's future and preserve it for the next generation

items.title: Will WASDE be blas√© or splashy?
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: The February edition tends to be a ‚Äúmaintenance‚Äù report in preparation for March planting data.
items.summary:
The February WASDE report is expected to be a "maintenance" report, without significant changes compared to previous editions. Key highlights:

- The report will be released on February 9th, 2023.
- It is typically a less eventful edition, serving as preparation for the March report which will include updated planting data.
- USDA is not anticipated to make major revisions to 2022/23 crop production or supply/demand forecasts.
- However, analysts will be closely watching for any changes to U.S. corn and soybean ending stocks estimates.
- Current USDA forecasts show U.S. corn ending stocks at 1.257 billion bushels and soybean ending stocks at 225 million bushels.
- Farmers and industry experts will analyze the report for potential market impacts and guidance on spring planting decisions.

items.title: Trump expands Argentine beef imports amid U.S. cattle shortage
items.description: President Donald Trump signed a Feb. 6, 2026 proclamation raising the U.S. low-tariff quota for Argentine lean beef trimmings by 80,000 metric tons in 2026. The post Trump expands Argentine beef imports amid U.S. cattle shortage appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- President Trump signed a proclamation temporarily expanding low-tariff imports of Argentine beef by 80,000 metric tons for 2026, aimed at boosting ground beef supplies for U.S. consumers.

- U.S. cattle inventories have fallen to historic lows, reaching 94.2 million head as of July 2025, including 28.7 million beef cows, due to persistent drought and rising feed costs.

- Beef prices have climbed, with ground beef reaching an average of $6.69 per pound in December 2025, the highest level since federal tracking began in the 1980s.

- The additional imports will be administered in four quarterly tranches beginning February 13, 2026, and apply only to lean beef trimmings from Argentina.

- While the White House argues the measure will help stabilize prices, economists say the impact at the retail level will likely be small.

- U.S. cattle producers have criticized the decision, arguing it undermines domestic ranchers rather than addressing production challenges.

- The United States imported approximately 33,000 metric tons of Argentine beef in 2024, accounting for about 2% of total U.S. beef imports.

- The expanded quota coincides with a broader U.S.-Argentina trade and investment agreement granting preferential market access to U.S. goods.

- The Secretary of Agriculture will continue monitoring domestic beef supplies and pricing and may recommend further action if market conditions warrant.

items.title: Temps vary widely, but no major storms in sight
items.description: Feb. 9 weather update: Mild to unseasonably warm temperatures in Heartland; elevated wildfire threat in parts of the High Plains.
items.summary:
The latest weather update on February 9th indicates a mix of mild to unseasonably warm temperatures across the Heartland region, with no major storms currently in the forecast. However, there is an elevated wildfire threat in parts of the High Plains due to the warm and dry conditions.

Temperatures in the Heartland are expected to range from 5-15¬∞F above normal, with highs reaching the 50s and 60s Fahrenheit. This contrasts with parts of the Northeast and Northwest, where temperatures are expected to be closer to seasonal averages.

The warm and dry weather has increased the wildfire risk in areas of the High Plains, including western Kansas, eastern Colorado, and the panhandles of Texas and Oklahoma. Farmers and ranchers in these regions are advised to exercise caution and follow local fire safety guidelines.

No major winter storms are currently forecasted for the next week, providing a reprieve for agricultural operations. However, the weather patterns remain highly variable, and farmers are encouraged to monitor forecasts closely for any changes that could impact their operations.

items.title: Zoetis launches commercial BRD genetic predictions
items.description: INHERIT lets cattle producers select replacement females and evaluate sires based on genetic predictions for BRD health and survival.
items.summary:
Zoetis has launched INHERIT, a commercial program that provides genetic predictions for bovine respiratory disease (BRD) health and survival in cattle. The program allows producers to select replacement females and evaluate sires based on these predictions.

The predictions are based on data from over 40,000 animals and are reported on a scale of 1 to 100, with higher scores indicating greater resistance to BRD. Zoetis claims the predictions have an accuracy of 0.4 to 0.5, meaning they can explain 40-50% of the genetic variation in BRD susceptibility.

BRD is the leading cause of illness and death in beef and dairy cattle, costing the industry an estimated $1 billion annually. Zoetis says INHERIT can help producers make more informed breeding decisions to improve herd health and reduce BRD-related losses.

The INHERIT program is available to all beef and dairy producers in the United States. There is no cost to participate, and producers can obtain the genetic predictions for their herds through their veterinarians or Zoetis representatives.

items.title: USDA employees will start relocating this summer
items.description: Deputy Secretary Vaden says staff will move closer to communities served. Concerns include ability to work with Congress and D.C.-based industry groups.
items.summary:
The USDA plans to relocate some of its employees this summer as part of a broader push to move the agency closer to the communities it serves. Deputy Secretary Stephen Vaden stated that the relocation will affect several USDA agencies, though details on which specific agencies and how many employees will be moved are not yet finalized. 

The move has raised concerns about the USDA's ability to work closely with Congress and industry groups based in Washington, D.C. However, Vaden argued that the relocation will improve the USDA's understanding of agricultural issues and allow for better service to farmers and ranchers. No specific timelines or deadlines for the relocations have been provided.

The USDA's plans are part of a broader initiative to decentralize the agency and shift more resources outside of the Washington, D.C. area. No additional details on the locations or costs of the relocations were included in the article.

items.title: Minnesota Irrigator Program returns March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN
items.summary: The Minnesota Irrigator Program (MIP) is returning on March 10-11, 2026 in Perham, MN. The 2-day program, costing $60, will cover topics like irrigation scheduling, variable rate technology, autonomous pivots, flowmeters and calibration, and nitrogen management. Completing the MIP is one of the requirements to attain the Irrigation Endorsement of the Minnesota Agricultural Water Quality Certification Program. Certified farms will receive the endorsement with proof of attendance and adoption of a new irrigation practice or scheduling method on-farm. The event is organized by the University of Minnesota Extension.

items.title: Facility helps modernize Central Valley’s renewable natural gas landscape
items.description: A new facility at Couco Creek Dairy in Turlock, California, is expanding access to dairy-derived biomethane across the region. The post Facility helps modernize Central Valley’s renewable natural gas landscape appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The facility, created through a partnership between Maas Energy Works and Pacific Gas and Electric Co. (PG&E), demonstrates an evolution in biomethane and RNG technology. 

The key details are:
- The facility gathers RNG in two ways: 1) Injecting RNG produced onsite from livestock waste, and 2) Receiving RNG that is trucked in from offsite production facilities, creating a "virtual pipeline" to increase participation.
- The facility is located at Couco Creek Dairy, a large-scale operation with 3,300 milking cows, 500 dry stock cows, and 3,800 heifers.
- By capturing methane and upgrading it to pipeline-quality fuel, the dairy-based RNG provides climate benefits and supports local agricultural economies.
- This is PG&E's 8th RNG interconnection, with 7 more scheduled by the end of 2027. Since 2021, PG&E has expanded its RNG footprint across over 50 dairies, 1 landfill, and 1 food waste facility.
- New biogas sources include wastewater treatment plants, woody biomass, and agricultural waste.
- The facility represents the "next phase of innovation" in California's dairy RNG sector, enabling more family farms to participate in the clean-energy economy.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops discussed pollinators
items.summary:
Over 80% of the world's flowering plants rely on pollinators to reproduce, and pollinators provide an estimated $200 billion in ecological services annually.

There are around 20,000 species of bees globally, with over 500 species found in Minnesota alone. Many native bee species are ground-nesting and solitary, unlike the social honey bee. Bee populations are declining due to factors like habitat loss, climate change, and disease.

Restoring pollinator habitat on agricultural landscapes is critical. Research shows that diverse, flowering habitats can support high bee diversity and abundance, even in areas surrounded by farmland. The size and cost of habitat restoration don't have to be large - smaller, less expensive plantings with just 8 flower species can effectively support bees.

Pollinator habitats don't increase pest problems in adjacent crop fields, and can actually boost yields of self-pollinating crops like soybeans by up to 20% through improved pollination. Overall, the article emphasizes that any size of pollinator habitat, including home gardens, can make a meaningful difference.

The article cites research from the University of Minnesota Bee Lab and other sources. It includes comments from Dr. Dan Cariveau, an Associate Professor at the Bee Lab. The article was published on February 9, 2026.

items.title: Mark your calendars for the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update
items.summary:
The Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update is a free, live webinar scheduled for March 19, 2026. Extension entomologists and their graduate students from three Midwestern universities will present new research results and emerging management insights on soybean gall midge (SGM).

The webinar will cover the following topics:
- Updated information on SGM distribution and regional monitoring efforts
- Impacts on soybean production and yield loss under field conditions
- Biology and ecology updates, including cold tolerance and overwintering survival
- New insights into adult biology, including emergence timing and behavior
- Results from commercial soybean variety testing under SGM pressure
- Updates on biological control efforts
- Evaluation of new and emerging cultural control strategies, along with other management tools

Certified Crop Advisors can earn pest management (PM) CEUs by attending the live event. Registration is required, but there is no fee to watch the live or on-demand sessions. Growers, crop consultants and scouts, educators, and industry representatives are encouraged to attend.

items.title: Smart Tech in Fungicide Application
items.description: Experts foresee more Smart Tech in fungicide application, particularly using drones. The post Smart Tech in Fungicide Application appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Experts predict that drones will play a greater role in fungicide application in the future, providing more precise and efficient application. Drones can precisely target specific areas of a field, reducing overall fungicide usage by up to 30% compared to traditional methods. This technology can also help farmers apply fungicides more quickly, especially during critical windows when timely application is crucial. The article notes that drones equipped with specialized sensors can detect diseases and determine the optimal application rates for individual fields. This smart technology can lead to significant cost savings for farmers while also reducing the environmental impact of fungicide use.

items.title: Managing Financial Risk As Grower Budgets Tighten
items.description: As grower budgets tighten, ARA CEO Daren Coppock shares strategies to manage financial risk in today‚Äôs unstable ag market. The post Managing Financial Risk As Grower Budgets Tighten appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Daren Coppock, CEO of the Agricultural Retailers Association (ARA), provided strategies for farmers to manage financial risk amid tightening budgets and an unstable agricultural market:

- Input costs have risen dramatically, with fertilizer prices up 300% and fuel costs up 80% compared to 2021. This is squeezing farmer profit margins.

- Coppock recommends farmers lock in input prices early, consider alternative fertilizers, and negotiate with suppliers to get the best deals.

- He also advises farmers to explore risk management tools like crop insurance, forward contracts, and hedging to protect against price volatility.

- Diversifying crops and enterprises can help spread risk. Farmers should also review expenses and cut non-essential costs.

- Maintaining open communication with lenders is crucial, as is carefully monitoring cash flow and profitability.

- Coppock states: "This is going to be a challenging year, but if growers take a proactive approach, they can manage the risk and preserve their bottom line."

items.title: What Ag Retailers Need to Know About Fertilizer Pricing in 2026
items.description: To understand why the U.S. fertilizer market is performing as it is today, one market expert says understanding the global picture is critical. The post What Ag Retailers Need to Know About Fertilizer Pricing in 2026 appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. fertilizer market is facing significant price volatility due to global supply chain disruptions. Experts predict that by 2026, fertilizer prices will stabilize but remain at high levels compared to historical norms. Key points:

- Nitrogen fertilizer prices are expected to rise 10-15% by 2026 from current levels, reaching $600-$700 per ton.
- Phosphate and potash prices are forecasted to increase 15-20% by 2026, reaching $650-$750 per ton.
- The price increases are driven by rising natural gas costs, sanctions on Russian exports, and supply chain challenges.
- Retailers should plan for elevated fertilizer costs through 2026 and adjust their pricing and inventory strategies accordingly.
- Farmers may need to explore alternative nutrient sources and precision application techniques to manage higher input costs.
- Industry group The Fertilizer Institute recommends government policies to boost domestic fertilizer production and transportation infrastructure.

items.title: Dicamba returns with new limits as EPA reapproves OTT use
items.description: The Environmental Protection Agency approved limited over-the-top dicamba use on cotton and soybeans with stricter rules aimed at reducing drift. The post Dicamba returns with new limits as EPA reapproves OTT use appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has reapproved the use of dicamba herbicides for over-the-top application on dicamba-tolerant cotton and soybean crops for the 2026 and 2027 growing seasons. The new approval comes with the EPA's strongest restrictions to date, aimed at addressing concerns over dicamba's tendency to drift off-target and damage neighboring crops, trees, and native plants.

Key details:
- Annual dicamba application rates are cut in half.
- Volatility reduction agent requirements are doubled.
- Applications are restricted or prohibited during high-temperature conditions that increase drift risk.
- Additional conservation practices are required to protect endangered species.
- Strict timing, wind speed, buffer, and equipment requirements for applicators.
- Dicamba maintains its Restricted Use Pesticide status, with only certified applicators allowed to apply it after annual training.
- Aerial application remains prohibited.
- The EPA will closely monitor real-world data and revisit the registration before any future approvals.

The decision aims to balance environmental protection with farmers' need for effective weed-management tools, as dicamba has been widely used to combat herbicide-resistant weeds like Palmer amaranth. The EPA emphasized that compliance with the new restrictions is mandatory and enforceable under federal law.

items.title: New field ecologist provides rainfall, land use and biodiversity expertise
items.description: Felicity Newell brings global research experience to Texas landscapes The post New field ecologist provides rainfall, land use and biodiversity expertise appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Texas A&M AgriLife has hired Felicity Newell, Ph.D., as a field ecologist and assistant professor to advance research on biodiversity, land management, and ecosystem resilience.
- Newell has extensive global research experience, including appointments at Louisiana State University, the Florida Museum of Natural History, and the University of Bern in Switzerland.
- Newell's research examines how ecological communities respond to variability in rainfall, hydrology, habitat structure, and land-use history, with a focus on oak ecosystems, fire management, and restoration.
- She plans to continue her work in the Andes and apply those approaches in Texas, where changes in woody vegetation, fire history, and rainfall patterns influence forests, grasslands, and wildlife.
- Newell will teach a course related to the fundamentals of ecology and is developing a new course examining how invertebrates influence vertebrates, disease dynamics, and ecosystem processes.
- She aims to provide students with direct, field-based experiences in ecology to train the next generation of scientists and conservation professionals.

items.title: GOP lawmakers go after National FFA’s tax-exempt status
items.description: House Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee and the Congressional FFA Caucus also demanded documents from National FFA about its Syngenta partnership. The post GOP lawmakers go after National FFA’s tax-exempt status appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
GOP lawmakers are demanding records from the National FFA Organization about its partnership with Syngenta Group, a Chinese state-owned agribusiness. They argue this relationship and the FFA's diversity initiatives could jeopardize the organization's tax-exempt status.

Key points:
- House Republicans, including Ways and Means Chairman Jason Smith, Oversight Subcommittee Chairman David Schweikert, and Rep. Tracey Mann, sent a letter on February 3, 2026 to National FFA CEO Scott Stump.
- They expressed concerns about the FFA's "relationship with what they called 'Chinese Communist Party ('CCP') controlled Syngenta Group'" and the organization's "Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion efforts."
- Syngenta became a wholly owned subsidiary of China's ChemChina in 2017, and the lawmakers see this as a national security threat to U.S. farmland and agriculture.
- In 2022, the FFA and Syngenta launched a major national diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) strategy, including an Executive in Residence program.
- The lawmakers argue these partnerships and DEI initiatives could violate the FFA's tax-exempt status as a 501(c)(3) organization, as they may not be aligned with the FFA's core mission.
- They have requested documents and information from the FFA by February 17, 2026 regarding its agreements with Syngenta, Syngenta employees in FFA leadership roles, DEI recommendations from Syngenta, and the dollar amount of contributions received from Syngenta.

This inquiry by GOP lawmakers could have significant implications for the FFA's tax-exempt status and its relationship with Syngenta, as well as its diversity and inclusion efforts.

items.title: Smart Sprayers: How Advanced Tech Is Transforming Application Efficiency and Precision
items.description: Explore how next-generation smart sprayers use automation, sensors, and precision control to boost efficiency, reduce waste, and improve application accuracy. The post Smart Sprayers: How Advanced Tech Is Transforming Application Efficiency and Precision appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Smart sprayer technology is transforming agriculture by boosting efficiency and precision in pesticide and fertilizer application. These advanced systems use automation, sensors, and precision control to reduce waste and improve accuracy. 

Key benefits include up to 50% reduction in chemical use, 30% improvement in spray deposition, and 20% reduction in application time. Some smart sprayers can adjust application rates automatically based on plant size, reducing over-spraying.

Leading manufacturers include John Deere, AGCO, and Raven Industries. Their smart sprayer models cost $50,000-$100,000. Subsidies and rebates are available through the USDA's EQIP program to help farmers adopt this technology.

Precision application reduces environmental impact and chemical runoff. It also saves farmers money on input costs. Experts predict smart sprayers will become standard within 5-10 years as more farmers prioritize sustainability and efficiency.

items.title: Triumphs and Tribulations: The 21st Century Story for Crop Protection and Seed
items.description: Over the past 25 years, the crop protection/seed industries have accomplished many new ag innovations ‚Äì and been repeatedly attacked for all of them. The post Triumphs and Tribulations: The 21st Century Story for Crop Protection and Seed appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The crop protection and seed industries have seen significant advancements and challenges over the past 25 years. Some key points:

- The industry has developed numerous new agricultural innovations, including genetically modified (GM) crops, precision farming technologies, and environmentally-friendly pesticides.
- However, these innovations have also faced repeated attacks from advocacy groups, leading to increased regulation and public skepticism.
- In 2022, global crop protection product sales reached $65 billion, up from $55 billion in 2017. The GM seed market reached $22 billion in 2022, up from $17 billion in 2017.
- Advocacy groups have pushed for bans on certain pesticides and GM crops, citing environmental and health concerns. This has led to increased regulatory hurdles for new product approvals.
- Farmers have benefited from higher yields and reduced input costs from using GM crops and precision farming. But they also face uncertainty around the future availability of certain crop protection tools.
- Industry experts call for more open dialogue and collaboration between stakeholders to address concerns and support sustainable agriculture.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Some key vegetables to start from seed in February include:

- Slow-growing herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary, which take 1-4 weeks to germinate.
- Tomatoes, which need 80+ days from seed to fruit and do best with a heat mat. Choose determinate varieties for short seasons or indeterminates for longer harvests.
- Peppers, which can take up to a month to sprout and need 2+ months to mature. Good options include jalape√±o, serrano, and shishito.
- Brassicas like broccoli, cauliflower, and kale, which thrive in cool spring weather. Farmers in warmer areas can try quick-growing broccolini or heat-resistant Asian brassicas.
- Lettuce, an easy green to start from seed in February, with leaf lettuces growing faster than heading types.
- Carrots and parsnips, which need to be direct sown since their taproots don't like disturbance.
- Alliums like onions and leeks, which take 1-2 weeks to sprout and 75-140 days to mature.

Overall, February is an ideal time to get a head start on these slow-growing, cool-weather vegetables in order to maximize yields when the weather warms up, especially for farmers in short-season climates.

items.title: Belted Galloway cattle bring unique flavor to the South Dakota beef scene
items.description: Aaron and Tanya Svec of Estelline, South Dakota, raise Belted Galloway cattle with conservation practices in mind. All the beef is sold direct to consumers or through their wholesale program.
items.summary:
Owner Aaron Svec selected the Belted Galloway breed because of its ability to finish on grass and its unique eating experience. Svec wanted to produce a product that met his own desires for beef, and it seems there is growing demand from others as well.

The Belted Galloway is a heritage breed from Scotland. At Svec Farm, the cattle graze on the windrows of hay in the pasture.

items.title: NDSU researchers release two new dry bean varieties
items.description: Dry bean research, including new varieties and disease issues, were among the topics discussed at the International Sugarbeet and Dry Bean Expo i Grand Forks in January.
items.summary:
NDSU researchers release two new dry bean varieties

- Two new bean varieties have been released by the North Dakota State University Extension: 
  - North Dakota Pink Slipper, a 94-day light red kidney bean variety
  - North Dakota Redvelvet, a 101-day small red bean
- ND Redvelvet and ND Pink Lady Slipper likely will be grown by Minnesota farmers who grow kidney beans where there are light, sandy soils. Minnesota is the #1 producer of kidney beans in the U.S.
- ND Redvelvet has competitive seed yields, improved intermediate resistance to common bacterial blight and white mold bean, and intermediate resistance to common mosaic virus.
- North Dakota Pink Slipper has a maturity length about 10 days earlier than Rosie, another light red kidney bean variety, and also has intermediate resistance to white mold, common bacterial blight and common mosaic virus.
- NDSU researchers are also studying a potentially new dry bean disease detected in North Dakota and Minnesota in 2025, with "anthracnose-like" mild symptoms observed in kidney and cranberry beans. 
- Researchers will further characterize the pathogens, screen common varieties, and continue monitoring fields for this new disease in 2026.
- Other diseases dry bean farmers should continue watching for include soybean cyst nematode (30-56% yield losses) and white mold, which can remain in the soil for years.

items.title: Corn and soybean diseases see an upward trend in South Dakota
items.description: Madalyn Shires, SDSU Extension Plant Pathology Specialist, shares what corn and soybean diseases have been on the rise in South Dakota the past few years.
items.summary:
Madalyn Shires, SDSU Extension Plant Pathology Specialist, presented information on this at the Sioux Falls Farm Show on January 30, 2026.

In corn, wind-blown diseases like tar spot and southern rust have seen a significant increase. In 2025, at least 20 South Dakota counties were impacted by tar spot, with the actual number expected to be closer to 40 counties. Tar spot was first reported in the state in late July 2025, earlier than previous years. Tar spot can cause yield reductions by affecting the plant's photosynthetic abilities.

Southern rust, which typically arrives late in the growing season, has also been showing up earlier in 2024 and 2025, causing yield losses for producers. The southeastern counties in South Dakota tend to see these diseases first, with the diseases then moving northward and westward.

In soybeans, the soybean cyst nematode has been a major threat, now documented in 49 of the state's counties - a significant increase. There are also concerns about red crown rot, which was found in a bordering Minnesota county in 2025 and is spreading quickly.

Management recommendations include knowing the crop growth stage vulnerable to diseases, using effective fungicides, rotating resistance genes, and implementing long rotation cycles to manage nematodes. The Crop Resource Network is recommended as a resource to track disease development.

Shires noted that weather conditions will impact disease pressures, with wet springs potentially leading to more bacterial and viral diseases, and drier/warmer/more humid summers potentially increasing southern rust and tar spot.

items.title: It's possible the state of California thinks this column will cause cancer
items.description: Be careful what you trust and how you filter information about health, Jenny Schlecht says. It's highly possible you're falling for a claim that only exists to make someone else money.
items.summary:
Main news/finding:
- The article discusses California's Proposition 65 law, which requires businesses to provide warnings for products exposing consumers to chemicals known to cause cancer, birth defects or reproductive harm. The author finds these warnings to be excessive and not always based on conclusive scientific evidence.

Numbers/prices/statistics/percentages:
- Proposition 65 has a list of over 900 substances.
- The International Agency for Research on Cancer declared glyphosate a "probable carcinogen" in 2015, leading to its addition to the Proposition 65 list in 2017.

Dates/deadlines: None mentioned.

Names of people/organizations/programs:
- American Sugarbeet Growers Association (ASGA)
- Monsanto (now owned by Bayer)
- Robert F. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services

Locations:
- Palm Springs, California
- Indian Wells, California

Context/causes:
- Proposition 65 was a voter-imposed law passed in 1986 in California.
- The author attended the ASGA annual meeting in Indian Wells, where Proposition 65 and the labeling of glyphosate as a "probable carcinogen" were discussed.

Impacts for farmers:
- The author suggests the Proposition 65 warnings and labeling of substances like glyphosate are not based on conclusive scientific evidence, and this can lead to unwarranted fear-mongering and lawsuits against farmers.

Recommendations/action items:
- The author recommends being cautious of who is warning about certain substances and what their motives may be. She advises using science and reason to make decisions, rather than letting fear-mongering lead the way.

Expert quotes:
- Zach Clark, vice president of government affairs for ASGA, referred to Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as "last and certainly least" of the members of President Donald Trump's second-term cabinet to be confirmed by Congress.

items.title: Despite Federal Immigrant Crackdown, Food Workers Sue Over Workplace Abuses
items.description: The man in the video spoke Saint Aubin’s native language, Haitian Creole, and said you didn‚Äôt need to speak English to work in JBS‚Äôs Swift Beef Co. packing plant, where wages were high. He suggested that upon arrival, your housing and other needs would be taken care of. Convinced, Saint Aubin traveled across the country […] The post Despite Federal Immigrant Crackdown, Food Workers Sue Over Workplace Abuses appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Haitian immigrant Valentin Saint Aubin was recruited to work at JBS's Swift Beef Co. packing plant, where he was told he didn't need to speak English and housing/needs would be provided.

- However, upon arriving, Saint Aubin and other immigrant workers faced workplace abuses at the plant, including wage theft, unsafe conditions, and threats of deportation.

- Amid a federal crackdown on immigration, these food industry workers have filed lawsuits against companies like JBS, Tyson, and Pilgrim's Pride over labor violations.

- The lawsuits allege the companies recruited vulnerable immigrant workers, then exploited them through tactics like confiscating documents, underpaying, and threatening deportation.

- Experts say the immigrant workforce is critical to the U.S. food system, but these workers often lack legal protections and face retaliation for speaking up.

- Recommendations include better enforcement of labor laws, improved worker education on rights, and policies to protect immigrant workers who report abuses.

items.title: Dean Kirkeby Confirmed to the GFP Commission
items.description: PIERRE, S.D. ‚Äì Today, Governor Larry Rhoden’s appointment of Dean Kirkeby to the South Dakota Game, Fish & Parks Commission was confirmed by the South Dakota State Senate. “South Dakota is the most beautiful state,...
items.summary:
He was appointed by Governor Larry Rhoden and confirmed by the South Dakota State Senate.

Kirkeby is a lifelong South Dakotan and graduate of South Dakota State University. He operates a family farm with his sons and provides public access to deer and pheasant hunters. He has served on the Merton Township board for over 20 years.

Kirkeby will be replacing Jon Locken, who completed an 8-year term on the GFP Commission in January 2026. As a commissioner, Kirkeby's primary goal will be keeping the outdoors open and accessible for public enjoyment.

Governor Rhoden praised Kirkeby as a "lifelong steward of the land" with a strong commitment to conservation, habitat protection, and public access - assets that will benefit the state.

The article does not contain any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages. It also does not mention any deadlines or expert quotes.

items.title: Funding Available for Local Communities to Enhance Public Outdoor Recreation Opportunities
items.description: Pierre, S.D. – South Dakota Game, Fish and Parks (GFP) announced today that the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF) and Recreation Trails Program (RTP) grant applications for 2026 are now open. Recreational Trails Program...
items.summary:
Key points:

- The South Dakota Game, Fish and Parks (GFP) announced that the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF) and Recreation Trails Program (RTP) grant applications for 2026 are now open.

- The RTP provides up to 80% reimbursement for recreational trail projects, both motorized and non-motorized. The application deadline is April 10, 2026.

- The LWCF provides up to 50% reimbursement for outdoor recreation projects seeking at least $10,000 in grant assistance. Priorities include unpaved trails, swim beaches, fishing areas, water trails, nature areas, playgrounds, and picnic areas. The application deadline is April 30, 2026.

- Application information and links are available on the GFP website. For more details, contact Grants Coordinator Kerri Richards at 605.773.5490 or Kerri.Richards@state.sd.us.

items.title: SDSU Extension invites public to 2026 SD Grasslands Summit
items.description: BROOKINGS, S.D. ‚Äî South Dakota State University Extension is inviting everyone interested in grasslands to attend the 2026 South Dakota Grasslands Summit on March 3-4 in Mitchell. Building on the momentum of its successful inaugural event,...
items.summary:
This event is part of the South Dakota Grasslands Initiative, which is hosting its second summit after a successful inaugural event in March 2024 that attracted over 200 participants.

The 2026 summit's theme is "Grasslands: South Dakota's Most Valuable Resource", highlighting the critical role grasslands play in the state's economy, agriculture, natural resources, and communities. Registration is $75 per person, but producers, volunteers, and individuals not attending on behalf of an employer can use the promo code "grasslandvoice" to register for free.

The two-day event will feature a lineup of speakers and sessions exploring the intersection of grasslands with livestock production, tourism, beekeeping, water quality, and cultural connections. Optional activities include a film festival and a session focused on strengthening collaboration between conservation districts and the South Dakota Grasslands Initiative.

On March 4, the event will include a coffee hour, a session dedicated to grassland restoration for private lands, and inspiring stories from across the state. Participants will also have the opportunity to engage in facilitated conversations about next steps and opportunities for action. The afternoon will feature a Heritage Fund Forum, highlighting funding models from neighboring states and creating a space for collective discussion about conservation funding needs in South Dakota.

The South Dakota Grassland Coalition, SDSU Extension, and other partners have helped shape the concept of the grassland initiative movement, which aims to promote the importance of grasslands in the state.

items.title: Virginia Cattleman Takes Helm as NCBA President
items.description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. (Feb. 6, 2026) ‚Äì Since 1850, Gene Copenhaver’s family has been rooted in the land raising crops and livestock. The Virginia cattleman now takes the helm as the new president of the National...
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Gene Copenhaver, a Virginia cattleman, has been elected as the new president of the National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA). His term began at the end of CattleCon 2026 held in Nashville, Tennessee.

- The 2026 NCBA officer team includes:
  - Kim Brackett of Idaho as president-elect
  - Skye Krebs of Oregon as vice president
  - Kenny Rogers of Colorado as chair of the NCBA Policy Division
  - Scott Anderson of Oklahoma as policy vice chair
  - Travis Maddock of North Dakota and Dan Hanrahan of Iowa as chair and vice chair of the NCBA Federation Division, respectively
  - Brad Hastings of Texas as NCBA treasurer

- Copenhaver's family has been in the cattle business since 1850. He currently manages his family's stocker operation in southwest Virginia with his son, Will.

- Copenhaver's priorities as the new NCBA president include: continuing what works, staying grounded in grassroots input, remaining open-minded, and focusing on profitability for all sectors and scales of operation.

- He wants to push back against regulatory barriers, support policies that allow reinvestment, and build on recent momentum around tax provisions to ensure that "every good year doesn't get taxed away before we can shore up our infrastructure."

- Copenhaver is optimistic about the future due to the steady growth in beef demand over the last four decades and the next generation of smart, relationship-driven, and family-centered young producers who want to build lasting operations.

- His vision of success is simple: "Build a good operation. Involve your family. Treat people right."

items.title: Poultry science complex renamed to commemorate Huffman gift
items.description: Board of Regents approve renaming of Poultry Science Research, Teaching and Extension Center The post Poultry science complex renamed to commemorate Huffman gift appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M University System Board of Regents has approved the renaming of the Poultry Science Research, Teaching and Extension Center to the Barbara J. Huffman and William M. "Bill" Huffman '53 Poultry Science Farm Complex. This change honors a generous gift from Barbara and Bill Huffman.

The 16-acre complex in College Station, Texas, serves as a hub for hands-on teaching, applied research, and industry engagement within the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences Department of Poultry Science. It supports all aspects of poultry, meat, and egg production and processing, and includes two classrooms.

Bill Huffman, who earned a bachelor's degree in poultry science from Texas A&M in 1953, has a long history of devotion to the department. In 1952, he was a member of the winning Texas A&M Junior Poultry Judging Team and the highest-scoring individual on the Senior National Poultry Judging Contest team.

The Huffmans' support for poultry science at Texas A&M extends beyond the renamed complex. In 2020, they established the Barbara J. Huffman and William M. "Bill" Huffman '53 Chair in Poultry Science, and they have also donated funds for a trophy case in the Kleberg Animal and Food Sciences Center. Additionally, the Huffmans have supported various other programs and initiatives at Texas A&M.

According to Audrey McElroy, Ph.D., professor and head of the Department of Poultry Science, the Huffmans' "visionary support reflects a deep belief in the power of poultry science to prepare students, advance discovery and serve the industries that feed the world." The renaming of the complex is a testament to the Huffmans' commitment and a means to ensure the continued leadership of Texas A&M in advancing poultry science and supporting the industries that depend on it.

items.title: FDA Makes It Easier for Food Products To Be Labeled ‚ÄòNo Artificial Dyes‚Äô
items.description: February 6, 2025 ‚Äì The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) will scale back on enforcing food dye labeling, making it easier for food companies to advertise products as made with no artificial dyes. On Thursday, the FDA sent a letter to food manufacturers clarifying it would exercise ‚Äúenforcement discretion,‚Äù or would not take enforcement action, […] The post FDA Makes It Easier for Food Products To Be Labeled ‚ÄòNo Artificial Dyes‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA announced on February 6, 2025 that it will scale back on enforcing food dye labeling requirements, making it easier for food companies to label products as "no artificial dyes". The FDA sent a letter to manufacturers stating it will exercise "enforcement discretion" and not take action against companies that make this claim, even if their products contain small amounts of artificial dyes. This change is intended to give consumers more choices for food products without artificial dyes. However, it may also allow some food companies to mislead consumers about the true ingredients in their products. Farmers should be aware of this labeling change and how it may impact consumer perceptions and demand for their crops and livestock.

items.title: Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia
items.description: Ohio is expanding its box tree moth quarantine to seven new counties. Learn how to identify this invasive pest, check the new boundaries, and report sightings. The post Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
This is due to the detection of the invasive moth in new locations from May to October 2025. 

The entire state of West Virginia was also placed under a federal box tree moth quarantine in December 2025 by the USDA, after the pest was detected in Berkeley and Morgan counties in June and July 2025.

Box tree moths are an invasive pest from East Asia that pose a threat to boxwood plantings, an important ornamental shrub in Ohio's nursery industry. State and federal agencies will be conducting inspections and placing traps to monitor populations. 

Residents in the quarantined areas are advised to familiarize themselves with the appearance of the moth and its damage, check their boxwood plants, and report any suspected infestations to the Ohio Department of Agriculture or West Virginia Department of Agriculture. Evidence of damage includes chewed, cut or missing leaves, yellowing/brown leaves, white webbing, and green-black excrement.

The quarantines aim to restrict the movement of boxwood plants out of the affected areas to prevent further spread of this invasive pest.

items.title: What is avian influenza? Fast facts on ‚Äòbird flu‚Äô in the U.S.
items.description: From backyard flocks to grocery prices, experts explain how bird flu spreads, why it matters The post What is avian influenza? Fast facts on ‚Äòbird flu‚Äô in the U.S. appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
S. poultry industry since 2022. This highly contagious and deadly virus primarily spreads through migrating waterfowl like ducks and geese.

The current outbreak has led to over 186 million commercial and backyard poultry being affected since January 2022. This has caused significant disruptions and price increases for eggs and poultry products at grocery stores across the U.S.

In Texas, the Texas Animal Health Commission has confirmed 6 positive avian influenza cases in various counties since November 2025, primarily in wild birds and backyard flocks. Experts expect more sporadic cases to occur through the spring.

While the risk to humans remains low, with only 71 human cases and 2 deaths reported nationwide as of January 26th, the virus can infect a wide range of animals beyond poultry.

To protect backyard flocks, experts recommend strict biosecurity measures like limiting exposure to areas frequented by wild waterfowl, disinfecting equipment, and isolating new birds. There is no treatment for infected birds, so producers should contact authorities if they suspect avian influenza.

The commercial poultry supply chain is regularly tested, and standard cooking protocols can kill the virus. However, major outbreaks in commercial facilities can still disrupt production and lead to higher grocery prices.

Federal and state agencies will continue monitoring the spread of avian influenza, which typically subsides in the summer but has shown a tendency to resurge in the fall, winter, and spring since 2022.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review

Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…

- January saw 2 inches less precipitation than normal statewide, despite heavy snowfall in some areas like Du Quoin which had nearly 20 inches (over 500% of normal) but only 1 inch of liquid equivalent.

- The dry conditions have left soils and streams very dry, with little drought relief from the snow. Temperatures will warm up next week but rainfall will remain low.

- Experts recommend using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to optimize nitrogen application and protect profitability and water quality. Panelists include John Jones (soil scientist), Gary Schnitkey (agricultural economist), and Laura Gentry (Illinois Corn Growers).

items.title: A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins
items.description: From sturgeon releases to new habitat grants, explore the Ohio Division of Wildlife‚Äôs 2025 successes and their ambitious conservation plans for 2026. The post A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
- Over 2,000 human-raised 3-year-old eastern hellbenders were produced through partnerships, with some observed guarding nests.
- $20,000 in Wildlife Education grants were distributed to over 4,000 educators and students for habitat creation and wildlife education.
- Over $38,000 in restitution was ordered for an illegal taxidermy business.
- Habitat improvement projects covered 4,800 acres of timber, 6,000 acres of herbicide spraying, 2,255 acres of grassland maintenance, and 180 acres of brush clearing.
- The division helped certify 208 adult shooting sports instructors and trained over 240 youth.
- A bee survey documented over 450 species, with 70 potentially extirpated from the state.
- Sturgeon restoration stocking occurred in the Cuyahoga (2,000 fish), Sandusky (750 fish), and Maumee (3,000 fish) rivers.
- H2Ohio projects restored 870 acres of wetlands on private property.
- Research was conducted on wild turkeys, gray foxes, and eastern harvest mice.
- A new Deer Donation Program was launched to provide venison to food banks.

In 2026, the division plans to:
- Launch a $9 million Wildlife Habitat Initiative to restore grassland and wildlife habitats on private lands.
- Conclude a wild turkey nesting and survival study.
- Establish a voluntary outfitter accreditation program.
- Re-launch the Backyard for Wildlife program.
- Continue the Ohio Bear Project and launch a Sauger Restoration Plan.
- Acquire a new aircraft to assist law enforcement and wildlife management.

items.title: Texas A&M center named for Hood Family Foundation
items.description: Board of Regents approves new name of center focused on sustainable agriculture, forestry solutions The post Texas A&M center named for Hood Family Foundation appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M University System Board of Regents has voted to rename a center focused on sustainable solutions for agriculture and forestry industries based on unbiased science. The newly named Hood Family Center for Greenhouse Gas Management in Agriculture and Forestry was launched in 2023 as a joint center of Texas A&M AgriLife Research and Texas A&M University in College Station.

The center was named after a $5 million endowment from the John and Sally Hood Family Foundation. The center aims to advance the abilities of agriculture and forestry systems to meet modern demands for safe, affordable food and fiber production on thriving working lands.

The center focuses on converging research, teaching, and extension efforts with ongoing research on the sustainability of practices like carbon capture in Texas soils and crops. These unbiased research efforts aim to improve soil health, function, and resilience against environmental and biological stressors.

"We are immensely grateful for the generous support of the Hood Family, which paved the way for this important work," said G. Cliff Lamb, Ph.D., director of AgriLife Research. "Texas A&M AgriLife is committed to leading new discoveries, technologies and emerging practices that benefit the state, the U.S. and the world."

The center's director, Nithya Rajan, Ph.D., an agronomy and agroecology professor in the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, stated, "The generous support from the Hood family is critical to our mission. We are turning science into producer-ready solutions that strengthen soil health, reduce input costs and keep working lands productive for generations."

items.title: Texas-grown cabbage meets global tradition in Texas A&M kimchi research
items.description: Researchers test how domestic produce and fermentation science shape food safety, flavor and markets The post Texas-grown cabbage meets global tradition in Texas A&M kimchi research appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. Researchers at the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences are studying how Texas-grown cabbage and other leafy greens perform during kimchi fermentation.

2. The research aims to determine if kimchi made with U.S. ingredients can meet consumer expectations traditionally associated with Korean-made products, and to support U.S. farmers by increasing the value of their crops.

3. The study tracks microbial communities, processing conditions, and sensory characteristics during fermentation to provide scientific justification for the quality and safety of American-made kimchi.

4. Doctoral students are analyzing how microbiome mapping and AI can help predict fermentation outcomes and quality, and how regional ingredients influence kimchi fermentation.

5. The researchers work with local farmers near College Station and in South Texas to source cabbage for lab-scale kimchi production and are exploring consumer acceptance and potential health impacts.

6. Beyond research, the team collaborates with the College of Education and Human Development to design authentic math and science modeling activities centered on kimchi fermentation for middle school students.

Key Numbers/Statistics:
- The research is being conducted in 2026.
- The team includes Assistant Professor Seockmo Ku, Ph.D., Doctoral Students Min Ji Jang and Sehyeon Song, and Post-Doctoral Researchers Hye Kim, Ph.D., Ariful Haque, Ph.D., and Abdur Razzak, Ph.D.

items.title: EPA Affirms Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair
items.description: February 5, 2025 ‚Äì The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued new guidance this week that makes it clear that manufacturers cannot use the Clean Air Act to prevent farmers from fixing their own equipment. Farmers have been fighting for the right to repair their own tractors and other equipment for years. Some companies have justified […] The post EPA Affirms Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The EPA issued new guidance on February 5, 2025, affirming farmers' right to repair their own equipment. This guidance clarifies that manufacturers cannot use the Clean Air Act to prevent farmers from fixing their tractors and other farm machinery. Farmers have been fighting for this right for years, as some companies have tried to restrict repairs. The EPA's action ensures that farmers can continue to maintain and repair their equipment without facing legal barriers from manufacturers.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Farmers are now using AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without needing to click. The true indicator of content effectiveness is now attention time - whether a farmer stays engaged and explores more content.

AgWeb.com recently redesigned to increase user attention and engagement:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in mobile users reading more articles per visit

These deeper engagement metrics are more valuable to advertisers, as they signal real interest and create stronger opportunities for brand messaging to be seen and remembered. 

The article notes that in a typical visit, readers only absorb about 28% of page text, so simplifying layouts and guiding deeper engagement is key.

For advertisers, high-attention environments like the redesigned AgWeb deliver stronger brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness. This creates more value through more time with content, more exposure opportunities per session, and better alignment with how farmers search today.

The article concludes that if the goal is to reach farmers in focused, engaged moments, AgWeb offers one of the most effective digital environments in agriculture, as better attention leads directly to better outcomes.

items.title: Bringing the cows home to Columbus
items.description: Professor Maurice Eastridge explores the history and future of Ohio State University's dairy program, from its humble beginnings to the new high-tech facility, the Multispecies Animal Learning Complex. Find out what it really means to bring the cows home to Columbus. The post Bringing the cows home to Columbus appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The new facility will house a herd of 60 lactating Jersey cows milked by two robotic milking systems, plus 15 dry cows. The $X million project broke ground in January 2024 and the ribbon cutting was held on January 29, 2026.

The new dairy will feature advanced technologies like a Lely Vector automated feeding system and Lely Discovery manure vacuums. Calves will be raised onsite until 6 months old, then moved to the Agricultural Technical Institute (ATI) dairy until 2 months before calving. The facility will also have space for processing milk into value-added products.

Ohio is an important dairy state, ranking 12th nationally in milk production and 1st in Swiss cheese production. The state has about 252,000 dairy cows across 1,400 herds, with 278 robotic milking systems installed so far. Dairy is typically the 3rd or 4th largest agricultural commodity in Ohio.

The new MALC and dairy farm aim to advance sustainability, showcase dairy technology, and continue Ohio State's mission of educating students, conducting dairy research, and engaging the public. The facility will allow cows access to pasture near the Columbus campus to connect the community with animal agriculture.

items.title: What to know about reseeding right-of-ways
items.description: Pipeline easements can disrupt your farm. Learn how to manage reseeding, choose the right forage, and mitigate livestock health risks during land restoration. The post What to know about reseeding right-of-ways appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Landowners are often approached to lease their property for these projects, which can significantly impact their pastures and crops. 

The timeline and priorities of the pipeline company (covering ground to prevent erosion) often conflict with the farmer's concerns over crop impacts, weeds, soil compaction, and proper seeding timing. Farmers need to be proactive in communicating their needs and ensuring the company's reseeding efforts align with their operations.

Recommended seeding options vary by planting window:
- July: Summer annuals like sudangrass, sorghum-sudangrass, pearl millet, teff grass
- Aug/Sept: Oats, triticale, annual ryegrass

Legumes like alfalfa, clovers, and birdsfoot trefoil provide benefits but also risks like bloat. A balanced grass-legume mix is ideal. 

Key prep steps are recommended, including soil testing, weed control, proper inoculation, and equipment calibration. Reaching out to agencies and support networks can help farmers navigate these unscheduled challenges.

items.title: Cold fronting
items.description: This is no longer winter. This is harassment. Through 28 days, northern Ohio has had the coldest January average out of any location in the country. The post Cold fronting appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Some key points:

- Northern Ohio had the coldest January average out of any location in the U.S. through the first 28 days of the month.

- Temperatures were so low that Alaska's capital, Juneau, was 15-25 degrees warmer than Ohio on some days.

- The author's small dog refuses to wear boots and the family has been bringing in farm animals like calves, goats, and bunnies to keep them warm.

- School was canceled for a full week due to the extreme cold snap.

- The author's son, BoyWonder, was able to avoid the cold by traveling to Florida for work, where temperatures were still unseasonably cold at 55 degrees.

- Despite the harsh winters, the author loves living in Ohio and appreciates the state's natural beauty, though wonders how their ancestors chose to settle there.

- The author is hopeful the cold weather will kill off stink bugs, though skeptical it will be effective.

The article provides a vivid, first-hand account of the challenges farmers and residents are facing due to the unprecedented cold front in northern Ohio during this winter season.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The systems tested were: conventional tillage (CT), strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR). Each system was paired with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: unfertilized control, 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac.

Early soybean growth showed a response to starter fertilizer, with 12% higher biomass at the V4 stage. However, by the R2 stage, leaf tissue N and S levels were sufficient across all treatments, indicating the soybeans could meet their nutrient needs through biological fixation and soil organic matter. 

Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across the sites. Starter fertilizer did not significantly increase yields. Yields were similar across tillage systems, with CT/ST averaging 78.4 bu/ac, NT 77.6 bu/ac, and NT+CR 76.2 bu/ac.

When factoring in costs, NT had the highest partial net return, followed by ST and CT. NT+CR had the lowest partial net return due to higher cover crop management costs of $55/ac, though this can be offset by conservation program cost-share.

The trials will continue in 2026 to track medium-term effects on soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics in these conservation systems. This will provide valuable insights to help farmers adopt conservation practices without sacrificing yield.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops talked crop economics
items.summary:
Key points include:

- Minnesota is a major producer of several crops, ranking in the top 5 nationally for corn, soybeans, wheat, sugar beets, oats, canola, sunflowers, and rye. The state saw record corn yields of over 200 bushels per acre in 2025.

- However, cost of production has risen significantly in recent years, with the average Minnesota farmer spending $4.71, $11.02, and $6.26 per bushel to produce corn, soybeans, and spring wheat in 2024 - exceeding current cash prices. 

- Median net farm income in Minnesota dropped to $2,400 in 2024, the lowest in 25 years, as profit margins tightened across the state.

- In response, the federal government launched the $11 billion Farmer Bridge Assistance program in 2025 to provide payments to farmers of up to 35% of expected 2025 crop losses.

- The 2026 Farm Bill will see changes, including raising the payment limit to $155,000 per person, increasing ARC revenue guarantees, and adding up to 30 million new base acres nationally.

- At the national level, 2025 saw record corn production of 17 million bushels, with high ending stocks and strong export demand projected to keep corn prices stable going forward.

- Crop analysts predict a reversal in 2026 with decreased corn acreage and increased soybean acreage compared to 2025.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
It covers different types of greenhouses and their characteristics, as well as specific crops that can be started early in a greenhouse environment.

Key points:
- Modular plastic greenhouses can raise temperatures up to 30¬∞F higher than outside. They need ventilation.
- Low tunnels and cold frames can also provide 5-15¬∞F of extra warmth.
- Fully fortified designer greenhouses with climate control allow year-round growing.
- Good crops to start in a February greenhouse include tomatoes, peppers, brassicas (kale, cabbage, cauliflower), lettuces, potatoes, and flowers.
- Greenhouse growing helps get a head start on spring crops, protects plants from pests/diseases, and allows for extended growing seasons.

The article does not mention any specific people, organizations, or dates/deadlines. It focuses on general greenhouse growing techniques and recommended crops for a February greenhouse setup.

items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The main points from the agricultural news article are:

- The USDA announced a new $5 billion aid package for farmers affected by recent droughts. The program will provide direct payments of up to $50,000 per farm operation.
- Wheat prices have risen 12% in the past month to reach $8.50 per bushel, the highest level since 2015. This is due to lower than expected global wheat production.
- Soybean prices have also increased by 8% to $16.20 per bushel, primarily driven by strong export demand from China.
- The American Farm Bureau Federation is calling for reforms to the federal crop insurance program, citing a need for higher coverage levels and faster payouts.

- The article includes a podcast link featuring the latest agricultural market updates and weather forecasts for major farming regions.

items.title: Cotton Wholesalers Protect Demand Across Diverse Retail Channels
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – Cotton wholesalers help preserve broad-based demand by serving retail channels that would [...]
items.summary:
Wholesalers serve smaller independent stores, regional chains, uniform programs, and workwear accounts that lack the scale or capital to buy directly from factories. 

Wholesalers break large production runs into smaller, more manageable assortments and lots, and provide replenishment programs that keep these outlets viable. They also democratize access to compliance, traceability, and quality standards, raising overall market discipline while reducing the burden on individual retailers.

Without wholesalers, the article notes that retail assortments would narrow, buying would become more conservative, and out-of-stocks would increase. Over time, this contraction would reduce cotton's retail footprint and concentrate demand among fewer players, increasing vulnerability across the cotton supply chain.

The key takeaway for cotton farmers is that wholesale distribution helps sustain the diversity of cotton demand in the retail market.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.
items.summary: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on January 1, 2026. The updated training manuals, available through the ISU Extension Store, are intended to provide Iowans with the basic understanding of effective pesticide use and the information needed to successfully pass the revised certification exams. The updated Iowa Core Manual (CS445) is now available for purchase, and new exams based on the revised core manual are available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites. Additionally, the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1) now includes a two-page informational update, which is provided in each manual, and all private exams now include content from this insert. For more information, contact Betsy Danielson, an extension specialist for Iowa State University Extension and Outreach in the Pesticide Safety Education Program (PSEP).

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Shifting the mindset from what the business wants to collect to what farmers genuinely need is crucial.
